content.description:
Buffer solutions containing <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="N a H C O 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaHC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> range in <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from 10.0 to 11.0. The chemical equation below represents the equilibrium between <math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>and <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the table lists the composition of four different buffer solutions at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium H C O 3 with a negative 1 charge aqueous plus O H negative 1 charge aqueous. K sub b equals 2.1 times 10 to the negative 4 power at 25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>at</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Buffer
 <math alttext="the molar concentration of N a H C O 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>NaHCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="the molar concentration of N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.question: Which mathematical expression can be used to explain why buffer 2 and buffer 3 have the same <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="the log of the fraction 0.200 over 0.200 equals the log of the fraction 0.100 over 0.100, which equals the log of 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.200</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.200</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the negative log of K sub w, minus the negative log of K sub b, which equals p K sub a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext></mrow><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>w</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>[</mtext><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext></mrow><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>)]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="0.200 molar equals 2 times 0.100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mtext>(</mtext><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="0.200 molar minus 0.200 molar equals 0.100 molar minus 0.100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the log of the fraction 0.200 over 0.200 equals the log of the fraction 0.100 over 0.100, which equals the log of 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.200</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.200</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
